intro: Fumaria muralis var. occidentalis, commonly known as the Western wallflower, is a flowering plant native to western North America. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its delicate, nodding yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or disturbed soils, often found along roadsides and in dry, open habitats. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while the stems are slender and branching. The species is known for its ability to thrive in harsh environments, making it a resilient and adaptable wildflower.
